# Cambridge IGCSE™

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 348, 293]]<|/det|>
## ADDITIONAL MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 154, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 277, 905, 293]]<|/det|>
0606/13  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 302, 905, 317]]<|/det|>
May/June 2022  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 326, 905, 341]]<|/det|>
2 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 228, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 880, 604]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 634, 219, 649]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 650, 728, 682]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 80.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[401, 76, 603, 94]]<|/det|>
Mathematical Formulae  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 136, 562, 156]]<|/det|>
## 1. ALGEBRA  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 168, 243, 187]]<|/det|>
Quadratic Equation  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 198, 390, 217]]<|/det|>
For the equation \(a x^{2} + b x + c = 0\) ,  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[420, 216, 584, 252]]<|/det|>
\[x = \frac{-b\pm\sqrt{b^{2} - 4ac}}{2a}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 273, 230, 291]]<|/det|>
Binomial Theorem  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[247, 294, 755, 333]]<|/det|>
\[(a + b)^{n} = a^{n} + \binom{n}{1} a^{n - 1}b + \binom{n}{2} a^{n - 2}b^{2} + \ldots +\binom{n}{r} a^{n - r}b^{r} + \ldots +b^{n}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 348, 495, 384]]<|/det|>
where \(n\) is a positive integer and \(\binom{n}{r} = \frac{n!}{(n - r)!r!}\)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 412, 391, 431]]<|/det|>
Arithmetic series \(u_{n} = a + (n - 1)d\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[250, 437, 536, 469]]<|/det|>
\[S_{n} = \frac{1}{2} n(a + l) = \frac{1}{2} n\left\{2a + (n - 1)d\right\}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 490, 336, 509]]<|/det|>
Geometric series \(u_{n} = a r^{n - 1}\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[248, 512, 432, 580]]<|/det|>
\[S_{n} = \frac{a(1 - r^{n})}{1 - r} (r\neq 1)\] \[S_{\infty} = \frac{a}{1 - r} (|r|< 1)\]  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[405, 613, 598, 631]]<|/det|>
## 2. TRIGONOMETRY  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 645, 160, 663]]<|/det|>
Identities  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[420, 673, 586, 725]]<|/det|>
\[\sin^{2}A + \cos^{2}A = 1\] \[\sec^{2}A = 1 + \tan^{2}A\] \[\csc \mathrm{e}^{2}A = 1 + \cot^{2}A\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 769, 245, 787]]<|/det|>
Formulae for \(\Delta ABC\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[405, 794, 598, 880]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{a}{\sin A} = \frac{b}{\sin B} = \frac{c}{\sin C\] \[a^{2} = b^{2} + c^{2} - 2bc\cos A\] \[\Delta = \frac{1}{2} bc\sin A\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 99, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 70, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
Find the rational numbers \(a, b\) and \(c\), such that the first three terms, in descending powers of \(x\), in the expansion of \(\left(3x^{2} - \frac{1}{9x}\right)^{5}\) can be written in the form \(ax^{10} + bx^{7} + cx^{4}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 100, 920, 119]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 485, 146, 504]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 476, 744, 509]]<|/det|>
Hence find the coefficient of \(x^{4}\) in the expansion of \(\left(3x^{2} - \frac{1}{9x}\right)^{5}\left(1 + \frac{1}{x^{3}}\right)^{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 485, 920, 504]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 698, 92]]<|/det|>
In this question, all lengths are in centimetres and all angles are in radians.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[364, 100, 631, 280]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 293, 920, 329]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a circle, centre \(O\), radius 8. The points \(A\), \(B\) and \(C\) lie on the circumference of the circle. The chord \(AB\) has length 10.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 341, 144, 359]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 341, 601, 361]]<|/det|>
Show that angle \(BOA\) is 1.35 correct to 2 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 342, 920, 361]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 511, 146, 530]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 511, 658, 530]]<|/det|>
Given that the minor arc \(BC\) has a length of 18, find angle \(BOC\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 511, 920, 530]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 667, 144, 685]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 667, 462, 685]]<|/det|>
Find the area of the minor sector \(AOC\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 667, 920, 685]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 97, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 146, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 75, 626, 96]]<|/det|>
Find the exact solution of the equation \(2\mathrm{e}^{6x} - 3\mathrm{e}^{3x} - 5 = 0.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 76, 920, 95]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 293, 146, 312]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 293, 504, 312]]<|/det|>
Solve the following simultaneous equations.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 319, 608, 349]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{e}^{4x - 7}\div \mathrm{e}^{5x + 7y} = \frac{1}{\mathrm{e}^2}\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[504, 355, 599, 374]]<|/det|>
\[xy + 18 = 0\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 355, 920, 374]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 78, 94, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 920, 116]]<|/det|>
Variables \(x\) and \(y\) are such that when \(\mathrm{e}^{4y}\) is plotted against \(x\), a straight line of gradient \(\frac{2}{5}\), passing through (10, 2), is obtained.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 125, 144, 144]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 125, 316, 144]]<|/det|>
Find \(y\) in terms of \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 125, 920, 144]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 514, 146, 532]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 514, 702, 533]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(y\) when \(x = 45\), giving your answer in the form \(\ln p\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 514, 920, 532]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 630, 144, 649]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 630, 529, 649]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(x\) for which \(y\) can be defined.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 630, 920, 649]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 96, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 920, 112]]<|/det|>
The velocity, \(v \mathrm{ms}^{- 1}\), of a particle moving in a straight line, \(t\) seconds after passing through a fixed point \(O\), is given by \(v = 6 \sin 3t\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 120, 144, 139]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 119, 771, 141]]<|/det|>
Find the time at which the acceleration of the particle is first equal to \(- 9 \mathrm{ms}^{- 2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 121, 920, 140]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 432, 146, 450]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 432, 616, 451]]<|/det|>
Find the displacement of the particle from \(O\) when \(t = 5.6\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 432, 920, 451]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 144, 92]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 272, 92]]<|/det|> It is given that <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[400, 72, 579, 92]]<|/det|> \[\mathrm{f}:x\to 2x^{2}\mathrm{\quad for~}x\geqslant 0,\] <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[400, 103, 599, 123]]<|/det|> \[\mathrm{g}:x\to 2x + 1\mathrm{\quad for~}x\geqslant 0.\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 134, 737, 154]]<|/det|> Each of the expressions in the table can be written as one of the following. <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 163, 715, 185]]<|/det|> \[\mathrm{f}^{\prime}\qquad \mathrm{f}^{\prime \prime}\qquad \mathrm{g}^{\prime}\qquad \mathrm{g}^{\prime \prime}\qquad \mathrm{fg}\qquad \mathrm{gf}\qquad \mathrm{f}^{2}\qquad \mathrm{g}^{2}\qquad \mathrm{f}^{-1}\qquad \mathrm{g}^{-1}\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 197, 641, 216]]<|/det|> Complete the table. The first row has been completed for you. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 198, 920, 216]]<|/det|> [5] <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[301, 228, 695, 609]]<|/det|>
ExpressionFunction notation
2g'
0
4x
8x² + 8x + 2
4x + 3
x - 1
2

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 75, 915, 109]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(\mathrm{h}(x) = (x - 1)^2 + 3\) for \(x \geqslant a\). The value of \(a\) is as small as possible such that \(\mathrm{h}^{-1}\) exists.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 121, 180, 139]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 121, 405, 139]]<|/det|>
Write down the value of \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 121, 920, 140]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 220, 180, 238]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 220, 405, 238]]<|/det|>
Write down the range of \(\mathrm{h}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 220, 920, 238]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 319, 183, 337]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 319, 455, 337]]<|/det|>
Find \(\mathrm{h}^{-1}(x)\) and state its domain.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 319, 920, 337]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 87, 94, 106]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 78, 504, 109]]<|/det|>
A curve has equation \(y = \frac{(2x + 1)^{\frac{3}{2}}}{x + 5}\) for \(x \geqslant 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 129, 144, 149]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 123, 767, 163]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\frac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x} = \frac{(2x + 1)^{\frac{1}{2}}}{(x + 5)^2} (Ax + B)\), where \(A\) and \(B\) are integers to be found.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 129, 920, 149]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 584, 143, 603]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 583, 576, 603]]<|/det|>
Show that there are no stationary points on this curve.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 583, 920, 602]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 816, 92]]<|/det|>
Find the approximate change in \(y\) when \(x\) increases from 1 to \(1 + p\), where \(p\) is small.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 72, 920, 91]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 336, 146, 355]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 336, 920, 371]]<|/det|>
Given that when \(x = 1\) the rate of change in \(x\) is 2.5 units per second, find the corresponding rate of change in \(y\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 351, 920, 370]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
A 6-digit number is formed from the digits 0, 1, 2, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9. A number cannot start with 0 and each digit can be used at most once in any 6-digit number.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 181, 135]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 117, 831, 135]]<|/det|>
Find how many 6-digit numbers can be formed if there are no further restrictions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 117, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 256, 181, 275]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 256, 655, 275]]<|/det|>
Find how many of these 6-digit numbers are divisible by 5.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 257, 920, 275]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 535, 180, 554]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 535, 710, 554]]<|/det|>
Find how many of these 6-digit numbers are greater than 850 000.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 535, 920, 554]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A team of 8 people is to be chosen from 12 people. Three of the people are brothers who must not be separated. Find the number of different teams that can be chosen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 84, 920, 103]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 79, 99, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 79, 144, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 77, 920, 102]]<|/det|>
Solve the equation \(3 \cosec^2\left(2\phi - \frac{\pi}{3}\right) = 4\), for \(0 < \phi < \pi\). Give your solutions in terms of \(\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 97, 920, 116]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 560, 144, 579]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 560, 724, 581]]<|/det|>
Given that \(2x - 1 = \cos \mathrm{e}^{2}\theta\) and \(y + 1 = \tan^{2}\theta\), find \(y\) in terms of \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 559, 920, 578]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 79, 106, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 79, 146, 100]]<|/det|>
(a)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 76, 240, 100]]<|/det|>
Show that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[253, 72, 737, 109]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{6}{2 + 3x} +\frac{4}{(x + 1)^2} -\frac{2}{x + 1} \quad \text{can be written as} \quad \frac{14x + 10}{(2 + 3x)(x + 1)^2}. \quad [2]\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 78, 920, 100]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 435, 144, 455]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 425, 917, 467]]<|/det|>
Hence find the exact value of \(\int_{0}^{2} \frac{14x + 10}{(2 + 3x)(x + 1)^2} \mathrm{~d}x\). Give your answer in the form \(p + \ln q\),

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 464, 437, 485]]<|/det|>
where \(p\) and \(q\) are rational numbers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 465, 920, 484]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]
